metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (Leaf area index of Daman Superstation, 2019)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the LAI measurements from the Daman superstation in the middle reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from June 1 to September 20 in 2019. The site (100.376° E, 38.853°N) was located in the maize surface, near Zhangye city in Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556 m. There are 7 observation samples, each of which is about 30m×30m in size, and the latitude and longitude are (100.376°E, 38.853°N)、(100.377° E, 38.858°N)、(100.374°E, 38.855°N)、(100.374°E, 38.858°N)、(100.371°E, 38.854°N)、(100.369°E, 38.854°N)、(100.369°E, 38.854°N). Five sub-canopy nodes and one above-canopy node are arranged in each sample. 
The data is obtained from LAINet measurements; the four-steps are performed to obtain LAI: the raw data is light quantum (level 0); the daily LAI can be obtained using the software LAInet (level 1); further the invalid and null values are screened and using the 7 days moving averaged method to obtain the processed LAI (level 2); for the multi LAINet nodes observation, the averaged LAI of the nodes area is the final LAI (level 3).
The released data are the post processed LAI products and stored using *.xls format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Qu et al. (2014) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for measuring leaf area index in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used for measuring leaf area index in arid regions is the use of a wireless sensor network called LAINet. This network automatically collects daily hourly light data from canopy nodes, which is then processed to calculate daily leaf area index.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in the ecological data collection in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas?
Example.Answer: One example of a challenge in ecological data collection in these areas is the degradation of the ecological environment, including the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, and intensification of land desertification, as seen in regions like the Tarim River basin and the Aral Sea basin.

Feature Specification.Question: What attributes are critical for understanding the oasis–desert interactions within inland river basins?
Feature Specification.Answer: energy exchange characteristics, water vapor exchange characteristics, carbon exchange characteristics, radiation, soil heat flux, temperature profiles, air pressure, precipitation, soil moisture

Quantification.Question: How many samples are included within each observational sample plot for the leaf area index data collection?
Quantification.Answer: 5 canopy under nodes, 1 canopy above node

Definition.Question: What does 'LAI' stand for in the context of environmental data collection, and how is it measured?
Definition.Answer: LAI stands for Leaf Area Index, which is measured using a wireless sensor network called LAINet. The network collects raw light data at various nodes, which is processed to calculate daily LAI values. Invalid values are identified and filled, and a 7-day moving average is applied to mitigate weather effects.

Definition.Question: What are 'eddy covariance systems' and how are they utilized in environmental data studies?
Definition.Answer: Eddy covariance systems are used to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data, including energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. These systems help in measuring exchanges between the surface and atmosphere in oasis–desert systems.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'data processing and quality control' in the context of hydrometeorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: Data processing and quality control refer to the stages of data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. This includes ensuring the accuracy and reliability of data collected from automatic weather stations and other sources, such as eddy covariance systems.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods using the LAINet wireless sensor network for measuring leaf area index compare to those using eddy covariance systems for energy, water vapor, and carbon flux measurements in terms of data granularity and frequency?
Comparison.Answer: The LAINet wireless sensor network collects leaf area index data with daily and hourly light data from multiple nodes, which is processed to account for weather variability. In contrast, eddy covariance systems measure energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes with half-hourly data, providing detailed temporal resolution for fluxes.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences and similarities between data processing techniques for the leaf area index dataset and the oasis–desert system dataset in terms of handling raw data and quality control?
Comparison.Answer: Both datasets undergo data processing and quality control, but the leaf area index dataset involves specific steps like filling invalid values and applying a 7-day moving average. The oasis–desert system dataset involves data collection, processing, and archiving, with steps to ensure data quality such as averaging meteorological data over 10-minute periods.

Interpretation.Question: How might the use of LAINet in data collection contribute to understanding the impact of climate variability on oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of LAINet enables detailed monitoring of leaf area index, which is crucial for understanding vegetation growth and health in oasis–desert ecosystems. By capturing data on a daily and hourly basis, researchers can analyze how climate variability affects vegetation dynamics and consequently the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in these ecosystems.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the integration of hydrometeorological data enhance the interpretation of oasis–desert interactions?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating hydrometeorological data, such as soil heat flux, air temperature, wind speed, and soil moisture, provides a comprehensive view of the environmental conditions influencing oasis–desert interactions. This data can help elucidate how these factors drive energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, thereby improving the understanding of ecological stability and the impact of climate change on these systems.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise when processing and validating long-term datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in arid regions, and how can they be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in processing and validating long-term datasets include dealing with missing or erroneous data due to harsh environmental conditions, sensor malfunctions, and data contamination. These can be addressed through rigorous data quality control procedures, such as identifying and filling invalid values, using multiple sensors for redundancy, and applying statistical methods to ensure data reliability and consistency.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying causes that necessitate the use of Level0 to Level3 processing in leaf area index data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The necessity for processing from Level0 to Level3 in leaf area index data collection is driven by the need to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the data. Raw data (Level0) is subject to fluctuations due to environmental conditions, so it undergoes processing to calculate daily LAI (Level1), identifying and filling invalid values and applying a 7-day moving average to mitigate weather-related impacts (Level2), and then averaging node values for final observations (Level3).

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the degradation of the ecological environment in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The degradation of the ecological environment in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas is caused by factors such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, land desertification intensification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are especially prevalent in regions along the Silk Road, like the Tarim River basin and the Aral Sea basin.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers impact the understanding of oasis–desert interactions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Long-term observations using these advanced systems can provide a comprehensive understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems. This can lead to better insights into the ecological stability, carbon cycle dynamics, and sustainable development strategies for these regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of including both artificial and natural oasis-desert systems in observational datasets for understanding the ecological balance in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Including both artificial and natural systems in datasets allows for a more holistic understanding of the ecological balance and interactions in arid regions. This can support more effective environmental policies and practices, contributing to the sustainable development and ecological security of these areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind collecting leaf area index data in arid and semi-arid regions using wireless sensor networks?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in these areas, supporting ecological security, and ensuring sustainable development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to conduct long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable for quantitatively understanding oasis–desert interactions, which is significant for protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases in arid and semi-arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of employing eddy covariance systems and automatic weather stations in oasis–desert areas for data collection?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes are to gather comprehensive datasets that include energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, as well as auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, to support research and decision-making related to ecological and agricultural productivity in oasis–desert systems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in the collection and processing of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection involves using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for half-hourly turbulent flux data, and automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data with 10-minute average periods. This includes observing radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, soil moisture profiles, and groundwater table data. Vegetation and soil parameters supplement the datasets. The process includes data collection, processing, and archiving for sharing.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key data processing techniques used to handle hydrometeorological data in arid and semiarid inland river basins to support ecological and socioeconomic studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Hydrometeorological data processing involves using automatic weather stations to capture various parameters with a 10-minute average period, such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature, and gradients of air temperature, humidity, wind speed, and direction, along with air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. The data undergoes collection, quality control, processing, and archiving for sharing, supporting the ecological and socioeconomic studies in these regions.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the processing and quality control of long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. Observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems include data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, while hydrometeorological data were observed from automatic weather stations.

Enablement.Question: How do wireless sensor networks contribute to the collection of leaf area index data in agricultural research?
Enablement.Answer: The Leaf Area Index (LAI) data were collected using a wireless sensor network called LAINet. The system automatically acquires light data from each node on a daily hourly basis, which is then processed into daily LAI values. Invalid values are identified and filled, and a 7-day sliding average is used to mitigate the effects of weather changes on the LAI calculation.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have facilitated the monitoring of hydrometeorological and vegetation parameters in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as automatic weather stations, eddy covariance systems, and scintillometers have facilitated the monitoring. These instruments allow for the collection of half-hourly turbulent flux data, radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles.

Expectation.Question: Why might the expected balance between oasis and desert systems not be achieved despite comprehensive data collection efforts?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road.

Expectation.Question: Why could there be discrepancies between the anticipated and actual effectiveness of long-term observational datasets in understanding oasis–desert interactions?
Expectation.Answer: Although long-term observations are indispensable for a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, challenges such as ecological environment degradation and climate changes could introduce complexities not fully captured by the datasets.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using wireless sensor networks like LAINet for collecting leaf area index data in arid and semi-arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of LAINet, a wireless sensor network, is effective for collecting leaf area index data as it allows for automated, high-frequency observations, which are crucial in capturing the dynamic processes in arid and semi-arid regions. The data processing methods, such as daily calculations and the use of a 7-day moving average, help in reducing the impact of weather variability, enhancing the reliability of the data.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how can existing datasets from oasis–desert areas be expanded or refined to better support ecological stability and socioeconomic development understanding?
Judgmental.Answer: Existing datasets from oasis–desert areas can be expanded or refined by incorporating more diverse data sources, such as remote sensing data, to complement ground observations. Enhancing spatial coverage and temporal resolution by integrating advanced sensor technologies and increasing the number of observation stations could also improve the understanding of ecological stability and socioeconomic development in these areas.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges of maintaining long-term data collection in oasis-desert ecosystems, especially with regard to energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in long-term data collection in oasis-desert ecosystems include ecological degradation, such as drying up of rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms, which can affect the stability and reliability of observational data over time.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets from oasis-desert systems are structured to include diverse parameters like energy fluxes, hydrometeorology, and vegetation in a cohesive manner.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets from oasis-desert systems are structured by establishing multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations that collect data on energy, water vapor, carbon fluxes, hydrometeorological conditions, and vegetation and soil parameters. The data is processed, quality controlled, and archived to ensure coherence and accessibility.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in collecting and processing ecological data in oasis–desert systems, considering the environmental and technical factors involved.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting and processing ecological data in oasis–desert systems include dealing with ecological environment degradation such as drying up of water bodies, vegetation degradation, and land desertification. Technical challenges involve managing data from multiple instruments like eddy covariance systems, ensuring accurate and continuous data collection and processing, and overcoming the harsh environmental conditions which can affect equipment and data quality.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for expanding datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions, focusing on long-term ecological and environmental monitoring.
Request/Directive.Answer: Strategies for expanding datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions could involve establishing additional land surface flux and meteorological stations, integrating more comprehensive auxiliary data such as vegetation and soil parameters, and using advanced data processing techniques for quality control and archiving. Long-term monitoring could be supported by collaborations with data centers like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center to facilitate data sharing and access.
